block.p: Theater

''THE LUCKY BROTHERS,'' a tale from the Near East, featuring puppets and actors, about two brothers who try to outwit their evil neighbor and a greedy king, using advice from their mother, who teaches them that they make their own luck. Presented by World Voices Club at New Perspectives Theater Company, 750 Eighth Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets, tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. For ages 4 to 9. Tickets: $6. Information: (212) 730-2030.
Theater

''THE LUCKY BROTHERS,'' a tale from the Near East, featuring puppets and actors, about two brothers who try to outwit their evil neighbor and a greedy king, using advice from their mother, who teaches them that they make their own luck. Presented by World Voices Club at New Perspectives Theater Company, 750 Eighth Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets, tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. For ages 4 to 9. Tickets: $6. Information: (212) 730-2030.

''MINOTAUR,'' a hip-hop version of the Greek myth, presented by members of Urban Youth Theater. The story about a teenager who is half-human, half-bull, imprisoned in a labyrinth features rap, break dance and body rhythms. Henry Street Settlement's Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side. Thursdays through Saturdays at 7 p.m. Through July 29. Tickets: $5. Reservations: (212) 598-0400.

''THE UGLY DUCKLING,'' a musical version of the fairy tale by Debra Kaye, with lyrics by Brenda Bell. Presented by Literally Alive at the Hitchcock-Rockefeller Auditorium, Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue at 53rd Street. For ages 3 to 8. Tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., with workshops at 1 p.m. Through Oct. 1. Tickets: $15; $5 workshop fee. Group rates for 20 and more. Reservations: (212) 866-5170.
Events

''THE ADVENTURES OF ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE AND FRIENDS,'' a series of selections from works by the television animator Jay Ward, through Sept. 17 at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Screenings are Tuesdays through Sundays at 12:15 p.m., with additional screenings Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Fridays at 7 p.m. Through Sunday, the screenings include the first 10 installments of Rocky and Bullwinkle's first adventure, featuring his arch-enemies Boris and Natasha. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

''BIRDS OF A FEATHER.'' Birds and their anatomy and survival abilities, will be the subject of a Science Club workshop tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George, led by Clay Wollney, an educator. For ages 8 to 13. Admission with advance registration: $8; $5 for members. At the door, admission is $10; $7 for members. Information: (718) 727-1135, Extension 15.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY presents two events tomorrow.The microscopic creatures swimming in the water of Turtle Pond will be the focus of ''Scoop and Snoop,'' a workshop from 1 to 2:30 p.m. at the Henry Luce Observatory at Belvedere Castle, mid-park at 79th Street. For ages 6 and up. Information: (212) 772-0210. ''Sketching to See,'' a sketching session with the naturalist Sarah Elliott, from 10:30 a.m. to noon at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue. For ages 10 and up. Information: (212) 860-1370.

''DIGGITY DEVON,'' a good-natured ''guitar-playing piggy,'' will perform at two locations this weekend. For ages 3 to 6. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., Staten Island Children's Museum, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, Staten Island, (201) 567-0560. Free with museum admission: $4; children under 2 free. Sunday at 2 p.m., at the Bronx Zoo, Children's Zoo Theater, Fordham Road and Bronx River Parkway, (718) 367-1010. Park entrance fee: $9; $5 for ages 2 to 12; under 2 free.

''THE DINOSAURS ARE COMING!'' Howard Zimmerman, author of ''The Biggest, Baddest, Strangest, Fastest,'' will talk about dinosaurs, and copies of his book will be available for a book signing, tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. at the American Museum of Natural History gift shop, Central Park West and 79th Street. Free for those attending only the presentation. Information: (212) 769-5731.

FREE FRIDAY FAMILY FUN, music, dance and comedy, Fridays at 6:30 p.m. through August at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Place, Crown Heights, under the stars in the rooftop theater. Tonight's program features Michael Rosman, the joke-telling, juggling unicyclist. Suggested admission to exhibitions: $3; shows are free. Information: (718) 735-4400.

''JUDY! JUDY! JUDY!'' ''In the Good Old Summertime'' (1949), a musical remake of Ernst Lubitsch's ''Shop Around the Corner,'' starring Judy Garland and Van Johnson, is part of the Judy Garland film series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, tomorrow and Sunday at 11 a.m. Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center. Tickets: $3. Information: (212) 875-5601.

''THE KIDNAPPED CANOE-MAKER: TALES FROM NATIVE AMERICA.'' Youngsters will hear stories about a kidnapped canoe maker and two canoes that raced each other and then create their own artwork version, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. at the South Street Seaport Museum's Children's Center, 165 John Street, Lower Manhattan. $2 materials fee. Information: (212) 748-8758.

NEW YORK FAMILY ARTS FESTIVAL, the second annual arts festival of multicultural performances and events, presented by the Theater of the Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue, at 120th Street, Morningside Heights. The festival runs daily through August. Tonight at 7, a performance by the percussion group Darryl Dove and Company. Tickets: $5. Tomorrow the theater will become a Brazilian Village, with a music and song workshop at 2 p.m., Capoeira Dance workshop at 4 p.m. and a Capoeira performance at 7 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 870-6784.

''THE PROMISE OF THE PARK,'' a walking tour and performance revisiting 18th- and 19th-century Central Park, Sunday, beginning at noon at 100th Street and Central Park West. The tour will end at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street, where Theater-in-Motion will present the musical production ''The Promise of the Park,'' at 2 p.m. The performance is free to people on the tour, which is also free; all others, free with a suggested donation to the museum of $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. To register: (888) 573-7554.

''PUPPETS, MUSIC AND THE UNEXPECTED.'' Short stories, presented by a cast of marionettes by Bernd Ogrodnik of Alchemilla Puppetworks, today at 4 p.m. at Queens Village branch of the Queens Library, 94-11 217 Street. Free. Information: (718) 776-6800.

''STORIES AND ART.'' What do Mother Goose, seafaring men, milkmaids and cowboys have in common? All these characters can be found in the art of the American illustrator Maxfield Parrish, whose work will be the focus of a performance by John Roberts and Tony Barrand, folk singers and storytellers, tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the Parrish exhibition galleries on the fourth floor of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.
Exhibitions

''FROM TENT TO TEMPLE: LIFE IN THE ANCIENT NEAR EAST,'' an interactive exhibition developed by the Jewish Children's Learning Lab, recreates the world of the Hebrews and other peoples of 3,900 to 2,900 years ago. In more than 30 displays, the exhibition challenges children to solve problems the way their biblical ancestors did. They can build a miniature plow, grind grain with stones or construct a hearth. Through Jan. 14 at the Center for Jewish History, Yeshiva University Museum, 15 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 294-8330. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free with admission: $6; the elderly and ages 5 to 12, $4; under 5 and members, free.

''REPTILES: REAL AND ROBOTIC.'' An alligator snapping turtle 10 times life size and a Western diamondback rattlesnake 36 feet long are part of the exhibition (through Sept. 17) at the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. Although those animals are robots, the real ones are no less impressive, including gila monsters, bearded dragons and blue-tongued skinks. Children will enjoy ''Reptiles Revealed'' shows each day in the hall at 1 and 3 p.m., and at noon and 2 p.m. they can see demonstrations of NASA's use of robotics. And through Aug. 26 the museum will offer shows of live reptiles every Saturday at 2 p.m. for $2. Hours in July and August: Mondays from 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Tuesdays through Sundays, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7.50; $5 for ages 4 to 17 and the elderly; free for children 3 and under. Information: (718) 699-0005.
Zoos

''IT'S POISON,'' a workshop at the Staten Island Zoo, Sunday from 10:30 a.m. to noon, on how animals use venom to protect themselves and kill their prey. Fee: $20 ($15 for zoo members) for family of three, including lunch; $5 for each additional family member. 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton. Preregistration required, (718) 442-3174 or (718) 442-3101.

REPTILE KEEPER WEEKEND ACTIVITIES at Prospect Park Zoo, 450 Flatbush Avenue, near Empire Boulevard, Crown Heights, Brooklyn, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4:30 p.m. Youngsters can join the zookeeper for a chat at 3 p.m. on the Barn Lawn. Other activities include transporting large toy snakes in the Snake Race. Zoo hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; weekends, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 399-7339.

Correction: July 15, 2000, Saturday A children's activity entry in the Spare Times column of Weekend yesterday misstated the date for ''The Promise of the Park,'' a walking tour and performance revisiting 18th- and 19th-century Central Park. The event, starting at 100th Street and Central Park West, begins at noon today, not Sunday.
Correction: July 15, 2000, Saturday

A children's activity entry in the Spare Times column of Weekend yesterday misstated the date for ''The Promise of the Park,'' a walking tour and performance revisiting 18th- and 19th-century Central Park. The event, starting at 100th Street and Central Park West, begins at noon today, not Sunday.
